Topic.Title: Don't forget NFLX $330 to 52? The time is coming for this too

Message.Msg: Are you saying that these other retailers can price-match amazon and still be able to maintain their profit margin and be profitable? LOL you're like one of those Apple fans who think Apple can price-match the Kindle and still make money. I'm saying it's *extremely* hard for any business to survive on razor thin margins. No business can compete with Amazon by cutting prices overnight. Amazon did this by scaling their business from the ground up over a decade. I bet retailers that price-match amazon are already losing money, and they're fighting a war of attrition. Amazon will win and the others will fold because they'll run out of cash before Amazon does. If you're comparing Google's "cloud" offering with Amazon web services, that just shows that you have NO clue what amazon web services really offer. Why don't you compare Amazon web services with Apple's iCloud since you're already comparing apples and oranges.

Topic.Title: Don't forget NFLX $330 to 52? The time is coming for this too

Message.Msg: I'ts gonna be a long time before some of AMZN's compeitiors run out of cash. For instance, AAPL and GOOG have multiples more cash than AMZN after years of making money. They are far from ever having to tap the bond market, which AMZN just did. It's AMZN who was running low on cash. Not that it matter in the analysis coming from Wallstreet or the algorithmic HFT program to keep running it higher for some hedgefund. But on a cash basis, you're wrong.

Topic.Title: Nuking AMZN Cashflow

Message.Msg: 75% of AMZN free cash flow is from working capital, and most of that is due to pushing supplier terms out. As revenue growth slows, the working capital story gets harder and harder and can reverse - they will quickly run out of cash.

Message.Title: buy the dip, sell the rip
Message.Msg: today's dump in premarket is setting up for a good buying opportunity...I am a buyer at $270! The worry over the debt ceiling will soon be resolved and AMZN's earnings will be good enough to keep the stock price from imploding, although many will sell the good news.

Topic.Title: Stock goes up... Fundamental goes down.. try to guess what is coming

Message.Msg: true, I think it's hard to know when it will matter: you;ve already had multiple qtrs in a row where the AMZN peak earnings of $2.52 disappointed the forecast that were placed way back to grow ON TOP of those $2.52 peak earnings. Howerver, the disappointment of not growing earnings was merely met with buying and changing the AMZN story. That's shown from the stock rally from 166.97 end of the year low to where we are now on earnings going toward 0. So it's hard to know if the lack of making money is considered a disappointment and what will qualify as one. WS has put on a fullcourt press to drees up AMZN as if there never was these past disappointment. It's called favoring the "loss leaders." And going on for quite some time now. Mom and Pop should run as far as they can from this kind of stock, no doubt, but that doesn't keep the HFT algorithyms from it and driving it up to the moon. If they can drive it to this level of nonsense,who knows what will scare them off. Certainly the fact that they had to hit the bond market shows that the fundemental case of not making money has made them have to get some. I've counted 5 recs by WS in the last 5 days on excuses mosly ranging from not worrying about not making money. My question is when do you then? It's now a $123 billion company as a loss leader. This is at,it's core, supported by Bernanke bucks. That's why the Fed deserve the abuse of unbridled printing to support market as it's gottonin the past from the likes of Ron Paul and Stephen Roach. It's should be translated as supporting nonsense, like the housing bubble and tech bubbles of yesteryear. AMZN is at the heart of it this time around. Certainly surreal to see AAPL crack and continued support of the loss leaders. That's a hedge fund phenomena in action. good luck.

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: Yeah, next trick will be to hook up a leaf blower with the Federal Reserve printing press...blow $1 and get $0.99 back... Same old same old...tax advantages are disappearing. The playing field is being leveled. AMZN about to get creamed by its competition. When the strategic picture changes, pay attention or you will be like AAPL longs. Once the picture is crystal clear, AMZN may very well be sub-100...

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: The argument was too early for years because: 1. Sales tax advantage. 2. Competition did not really care for AMZN. Now, sales tax advantage is going away and, the competition having seen AMZN proving the online model, they are now going after AMZN on its own turf. Think AAPL proving that there is a highly profitable market for nice, upscale, a touch-of-upper class feel smart phones and apps for everyone one. Now, the competition (like Samsung) sees that there is a market, they are going after what AAPL had had to build. And, what happened to AAPL stock price? Note: AAPL stock price got hit simply due to a change in the strategic prospect. AAPL is makes a ton of money, but the strategic picture changed. The smart ones saw the change 7-9 months ago.

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: stock_lol... apple sells phones period. Nok, Rimm sold phones too.... all the way up and all the way down... not saying that is fate of apple, but that could be a fate of any hardware manufacturer in a commodity market. Yeah, they had immense success that build that cash horde...but what have they done for "markets" lately?? who is going to keep buying phones every 3 months?? I've argued that apple should use their money and get into other lines of businesses and if they don't, their cash is seen as drag on their balance sheet. Apple under Cook is not a good. Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: So, idbtc, what does AMZN sell, but commodities that thousands of other folks are selling? You realize AMZN makes second-class hardware such as Kindles right? AMZN sells them at a LOSS whereas AAPL sells their stuff with huge margin. Now, I'm straddling the fence regarding AAPL strategic view. However, to think of AAPL as just another box maker is plainly wrong. Another fact is that, in the face of world-wide competition, the AAPL team has THRIVED. That's a proven team. They brought the dough home. What the heck has AMZN mgmt team done so far?

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: stock_lol...I guess we agree to disagree. That is what makes a market. And AMZN is about technology infrastructure and building the platform..not to confuse with the items that they are selling..that is other people's business, Amzn provides the infrastructure - scalable which is key and no borders - yes, they still have to deal with growing regulation on ecommerce but nothing on the horizon suggest ecommerce will be choked off by regulations. Kindle might be sold at a loss to get users onto the platform, and I would argue that is where the upside is... suppose they get more traction and sell at a gain? whereas apple is going the other way, their huge margins in a commodity business is unsustainable. And Apple's mgmt team ex-Jobs is less than impressive, this is not Jobs Apple anymore. I don't see resizing ipad and iphones as innovation. Cook is a liability for apple.

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Message.Msg: The bulls see a story that has been continually reinforced by CNBC and the financial media, but one that simply does not hold up to rigorous analysis. Amazon is far more levered than the investing public has been led to believe. Sustainable cash flows misrepresent the true FCF growth. There are so many places to do with this... This will be a much better story for Bethany McLean than the last one...

Message.Title: idbtc? what is the affect of high oil prices to the door to door delivery model for AMZN?
Message.Msg: as they gotton more topline scale, they've lost more money? Media says it's about investment, but invesmtnet is capitalized balance sheet items that are amortized in most cases, so quarterly earnings should not be so affected. I 'd be interested to here you view in a world where paper printing ain't helping the price of oil or the price of transporting bulk go down when it's door to door. In that case, the whole profit model is a sham. They just hit the bond market to prove that more cash is needed that's not being provided by ongoing earnings.

Topic.Title: idbtc? what is the affect of high oil prices to the door to door delivery model for AMZN?

Message.Msg: Party: I've done the analysis. It isn't just a function of higher oil prices. But, the conclusion you reach is correct (although this would have massive downside even if oil slipped because the economic driver isn't oil price per se, that just happens to reinforce the effect). Amazon is a scam. Amazon is moving closer toward being a brick and mortar retailer every day, yet its multiple continues to diverge from that of bricks and mortar. One would think at least 1 analyst out there would catch the irony in that. The math doesn't work and will not work. And, it will get worse in time. Having said that, the tail risk for this company is greater than any other in the world. Bar none.

Topic.Title: Owes $1.5 Billion to IRS

Message.Msg: Amazon fights $234 million tax liability in Tax Court. Amazon first publicly disclosed in April 2011 that it faces $1.5 billion in additional federal taxes over a seven-year period, beginning in 2005, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Amazon faces other tax troubles in the United States and abroad. Amazon received a $252 million demand from French tax authorities at the end of last year. Amazon last year was forced to start collecting sales taxes in more states, including California, Texas and Pennsylvania. --New out today Reuters. Please read before accusing.. Aye!

Topic.Title: Owes $1.5 Billion to IRS

Message.Msg: Just seeing a new alias with no posting history... I am always suspicious of that. The article is fact. But, I increasingly think there are bigger issues... I'm going to do some more due diligence around the disclosures of cash position and tax liability at the time of the debt offering... Amazon had been notified of by the IRS at that time. At first glance, I saw none. I find that remarkable given the possible cash flow issues Amazon had at the time of the offering (in Q3 net ST assets and liabilities were about equal and the shipping/advertising had to burn cash). I'm going to ask an expert on securities regulation (have one in the family...). There are a few things that don't smell right here.

Topic.Title: that is why Amzn has super charged PE

Somebody tell me how long it would take AMZN to come to a P/E level that makes sense. In short time AMZN will have to collect taxes on all that they sell, that amounts to 9.75 % in my state. HELLO Yet AMZN is going up while AAPL is going down WOW I have no position in either, but if I would well

Topic.Title: Owes $1.5 Billion to IRS

Message.Msg: Sybs: You disclose your identity and besides that, the style is unique. I have posted under 1 other alias when blocked and always disclose. My issue is with people creating additional aliases to spam the board... Still researching the debt financing documents for disclosures of then current cash position and IRS tax issue... I have yet to find anything that provides more updated financials than the previous quarter (particularly cash position as of the financing) and explicit recognition of the IRS claim. I am surprised by the lack of explicit disclosure of these items which changed materially after the Q3 report. From the registration: Actual results could differ materially for a variety of reasons, including, among others, fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, changes in global economic conditions and consumer spending, world events, the rate of growth of the Internet and online commerce, the amount that we invest in new business opportunities and the timing of those investments, the mix of products sold to customers, the mix of net sales derived from products as compared with services, THE EXTENT TO WHICH WE OWE INCOME TAXES, competition, management of growth, potential fluctuations in operating results, international growth and expansion, the outcomes of legal proceedings and claims, fulfillment center optimization, risks of inventory management, seasonality, the degree to which the Registrant enters into, maintains, and develops commercial agreements, acquisitions, and strategic transactions, payments risks, and risks of fulfillment throughput and productivity. In addition, the current global economic climate amplifies many of these risks. These risks and uncertainties, as well as other risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ significantly from management’s expectations, are described in greater detail in our Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended September 30, 2012, under “Item 1A. Risk Factors.” It seems that material facts were OMITTED from bondholders...
